build up.translation[0].definitions[0].d: if something builds up somewhere, or if you build it up, it gradually becomes bigger or greater
build up.translation[0].definitions[0].e: the rate at which the pension builds up
The museum has built up a fine art collection.
build up.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to make something develop or form
build up.translation[0].definitions[1].e: He’s built up the family firm into a multinational company.
build up.translation[0].definitions[2].d: if a feeling builds up, or if you build it up, it increases gradually over a period of time
build up.translation[0].definitions[2].e: If you don’t express your feelings, frustration and anger can build up.
You have to build up trust.
build up.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to make someone well and strong again, especially after an illness
build up.translation[0].definitions[3].e: Taking exercise will build up your strength.
build up.translation[0].definitions[4].d: to praise someone or something so that other people think they are really good, or so that they have more confidence
build up.translation[0].definitions[4].e: The coach has been building his men up before the match.
build up.translation[0].definitions[5].d: to unfairly encourage someone to think that they will get what they hope for
build up.translation[0].definitions[5].e: Don’t build your hopes up too much.
build up.translation[1].definitions[0].d: an increase over a period of time
build up.translation[1].definitions[0].e: a heavy build-up of traffic on the motorway
build up.translation[1].definitions[1].d: a description of someone or something before an event, in which you say they are very special or important
build up.translation[1].definitions[1].e: The presenter gave her a big build-up.
build up.translation[1].definitions[2].d: the length of time spent preparing an event
build up.translation[1].definitions[2].e: I was running 20 miles a week in my build-up for the race.
